docs.snippet: WHEN Jon Faddis, the trumpeter who is now the artist-in-residence at Purchase College's jazz studies program, was 12, his parents took him to a supper club in San Francisco so he could hear his musical idol, Dizzy Gillespie, perform.    After the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Jon Faddis, the trumpeter who is now the artist-in-residence at Purchase College's jazz studies program, was 12, his parents took him to a supper club in San Francisco so he could hear his musical idol, Dizzy Gillespie, perform. After the show, Mr. Faddis said, he was introduced to the legendary trumpeter and band leader, ''but I was too shy to say anything to him.''
docs.abstract: Article on trumpeter Jon Faddis, who will pay homage to his mentor, Dizzy Gillespie, with New York Big Band All Stars, in concert at Pepsico Theater at Purchase College, Purchase, NY; photo (M)

headline.main: Trumpeter Pays Homage to Dizzy Gillespie

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NEW YORK BIG BAND ALL STARS

docs.snippet: Stan Freeman, the pianist, composer, comedian and writer who was a ubiquitous presence in New York nightclubs in 1950's and 60's, was found dead in his home in Los Angeles last Saturday. He was 80.    A classically trained pianist, renowned wit an...
docs.lead_paragraph: Stan Freeman, the pianist, composer, comedian and writer who was a ubiquitous presence in New York nightclubs in 1950's and 60's, was found dead in his home in Los Angeles last Saturday. He was 80. A classically trained pianist, renowned wit and passionate musical theater archivist, Mr. Freeman straddled many different areas of entertainment, including nightclubs, radio, television, Broadway and recordings. Born in Waterbury, Conn., he graduated from the University of Hartford and during World War II played in Glenn Miller's Army Air Force Band. After the war he joined Tex Beneke's orchestra as a pianist. He also teamed up with the pianist Cy Walter to make several duo piano albums as well as recordings with Mabel Mercer and Lee Wiley.
docs.abstract: Stan Freeman, nightclub pianist, dies at age 80; photo (M)

docs.snippet: ''Tamicanfly,'' a play named for a 12-year-old racehorse listed as a 30-to-1 shot at the track in Yakima, Wash., can't be listed among theater's thoroughbreds.    Oh, this comedy by Scott Marshall Taylor at the McGinn/Cazale Theater moves along br...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Tamicanfly,'' a play named for a 12-year-old racehorse listed as a 30-to-1 shot at the track in Yakima, Wash., can't be listed among theater's thoroughbreds. Oh, this comedy by Scott Marshall Taylor at the McGinn/Cazale Theater moves along briskly enough under the direction of Ethan McSweeny, who staged the recent Broadway revival of ''The Best Man.'' But the five characters who eventually come together in a diner near the racetrack are unevenly drawn, and the play as a whole, with its underlying hopefulness about life's possibilities, never achieves the whimsical charm it needs to be a winner.
docs.abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder reviews Scott Marshall Taylor's play Tamicanfly, directed by Ethan McSweeney; Robert Walden stars (M)

headline.main: Got the Horse Right Here, Its Name Is Tamicanfly

docs.lead_paragraph: SHULMAN-Oscar. Of Elmira, N.Y. on January 16, 2001. Survived by daughter Dori Shulman Sokolowski of Prescott Valley, AZ., three grandchildren and one great grandchild. Services at Congregation Shomray Hadath today, 11AM. Oscar was former President of I. Shulman & Son Co., Inc., NY State Chapter Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel. past Director at Large, Eastern Region, National Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel.

docs.snippet: The New York attorney general's office has filed a federal civil rights complaint yesterday against the small upstate town of Wallkill, charging that it has failed to corral a lawless police department whose officers pull over female drivers to so...
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general's office has filed a federal civil rights complaint yesterday against the small upstate town of Wallkill, charging that it has failed to corral a lawless police department whose officers pull over female drivers to solicit dates, refuse to cooperate with other law enforcement agencies, and systematically harass their many critics, from town officials to the local newspaper. With news of the aggressive action, an Orange County town formerly known best for a mall, the Galleria at Crystal Run, and the city of Middletown suddenly found itself being described as the Catskill equivalent of ''Copland,'' and the subject of unfamiliar and unwanted attention. The initial reaction of some residents was to discount the charges as minor and nothing they could not take care of themselves.
docs.abstract: New York attorney general's office files federal civil rights complaint against town of Wallkill, charging that it has failed to corral lawless police department whose officers pull over female drivers to solicit dates, refuse to cooperate with other law enforcement agencies and harass critics; map (M)

headline.main: Seeing Lawless Police Behavior, State Files Civil Rights Complaint Against Small Town

docs.snippet: KEVIN COSTNER fidgeted on the plush sofa in the back row of the basement screening room in his Hollywood Hills compound. A slight grimace crossed his face. It's true, Mr. Costner said, he did feel a little uncomfortable. ''I don't usually tolerate...
docs.lead_paragraph: KEVIN COSTNER fidgeted on the plush sofa in the back row of the basement screening room in his Hollywood Hills compound. A slight grimace crossed his face. It's true, Mr. Costner said, he did feel a little uncomfortable. ''I don't usually tolerate people talking through movies,'' he said. ''My kids don't talk. They know.'' Talking during movies is a common annoyance, as anyone who has felt the fierce wave of shushes roll across a theater at the beginning of a movie can confirm. To many filmmakers it is a particular irritation, and Mr. Costner is one of them. But it can't be helped. It's the nature of the event. Mr. Costner has been asked to choose, from his favorite films, one that has some particular strength or resonance to him and to talk about the impact it has had on him and his fresh impressions of it as he sat through another viewing.
docs.abstract: Article in series Watching Movies With interviews Kevin Costner during screening of Cool Hand Luke; Costner discusses his own acting and directing and special inspiration of Paul Newman; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Mexico's Supreme Court ruled tonight that a Mexican citizen charged as a cocaine kingpin in a United States court could be extradicted to California, a precedent-setting decision long sought by American authorities.     The case of the trafficker,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mexico's Supreme Court ruled tonight that a Mexican citizen charged as a cocaine kingpin in a United States court could be extradicted to California, a precedent-setting decision long sought by American authorities. The case of the trafficker, Arturo Paez Martinez, who was charged in a federal indictment in San Diego with smuggling more than 2,200 pounds of cocaine into the United States, was seen on both sides of the border as a test of Mexico's willingness to extradite people accused of drug trafficking to face American justice. In a companion ruling, the court said a reputed lieutenant in another drug cartel, Oscar Malherbe de Leon, could also be extradited to the United States.
docs.abstract: Mexico's Supreme Court rules that Mexican citizen charged as cocaine kingpin in United States court could be extradited to California, precedent-setting decision long sought by American authorities; case of trafficker, Arturo Paez Martinez, is seen on both sides of border as test of Mexico's willingness to extradite people accused of drug trafficking to face American justice; court, in companion ruling, says reputed lieutenant in another drug cartel, Oscar Malherbe de Leon, could also be extradited to United States (M)

headline.main: Mexico Agrees To Extradite Drug Suspect To California

docs.snippet: Many businesses crank back a notch in mid-January, still sluggish from holiday revels and the chill of winter. But this is an especially busy time in Hollywood, what with the awards season in full swing, the first of the year's big releases being ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Many businesses crank back a notch in mid-January, still sluggish from holiday revels and the chill of winter. But this is an especially busy time in Hollywood, what with the awards season in full swing, the first of the year's big releases being prepared to open and the arrival of another Sundance Film Festival in the snows of the Wasatch Range high above Salt Lake City. But this year is, if anything, more frenetic than most because there is also the double threat of strikes by the Writers Guild of America (in late May) and the Screen Actors Guild (in late June), which could pretty much shut down the entertainment industry in Los Angeles. As a result, movie studios are scrambling to finish as many films as they can before the strike deadlines, so everyone is frantically hopping from project to project with barely a breath in between.
docs.abstract: At the Movies column; studios scramble to complete films before spring strike deadlines set by Writers Guild and Screen Actors Guild; Michael Caine is filming Graham Greene's Quiet American in Australia and then Boswell for the Defense; composer Hans Zimmer discusses his scores for Hannibal, Gladiator and other movies; photo; screenwriter Adam Brooks will attend his first Sundance festival as director, of The Invisible Circus; Anne DeSalvo awaits opening of The Amati Girls, her first feature film as director (M)

docs.snippet: How many gowns does a woman -- the regular kind, who will never thank the William Morris Agency in a televised awards ceremony -- actually need? This is a question repeatedly asked by those who live at some remove from fashion's orbit, and one tha...
docs.lead_paragraph: How many gowns does a woman -- the regular kind, who will never thank the William Morris Agency in a televised awards ceremony -- actually need? This is a question repeatedly asked by those who live at some remove from fashion's orbit, and one that sociologists have seemingly been remiss to explore. But last week, Laura Royter-Shvarts, a Russian immigrant with a penchant for Vanna White glamour, arrived at an estimate: 24 a year. Ms. Royter-Shvarts, 34, a former financial analyst and a mother of two, based the figure on the habits of those in her own rarefied world, the subculture of newly well-to-do Russians who have built mansionettes in the Mill Basin and Manhattan Beach sections of Brooklyn.
docs.abstract: Article discusses apparel shops on King's Highway in Brooklyn that cater to newly prosperous Russian immigrants; photo (M)

headline.main: Where the Belles of Brooklyn Shop

docs.snippet: AFTER graduating from college with a bachelor's degree in fine arts 26 years ago, Mitche Kunzman entered the world of art dealing. He apprenticed under Oscar Leneman, who at that time owned Lenem Arts, a company that dealt in art from India, old m...
docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER graduating from college with a bachelor's degree in fine arts 26 years ago, Mitche Kunzman entered the world of art dealing. He apprenticed under Oscar Leneman, who at that time owned Lenem Arts, a company that dealt in art from India, old master prints and Japanese woodcuts. Reminiscing, Mr. Kunzman said: ''Here I am, 25 years old, selling Indian paintings to interior design firms in such far away places as Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. Then, a little while later, I find myself in Cleveland during one of their worst blizzards of the century, writing an order at Higby's Department store.''
docs.abstract: Article on art dealer and artist Mitche Kunzman of Lewisboro, NY, expert in Indian paintings from 16th to 19th centuries, and his wife, Helen, a potter, who own Artifacts Collections of New York; photos (M)

headline.main: Collectors of Art, and Artists Themselves
